article.headline: Colorado 81, Baylor 66
article.story: BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Dunks, layups, finger rolls, short jumpers -- David Harrison hit them all. Harrison scored 26 points on 10-of-10 shooting and also had 10 rebounds, leading Colorado to an 81-66 win over Baylor on Saturday night. Harrison's perfect shooting was a school record, eclipsing the 9-of-9 by John Addison against Midwestern State in 1979. "I'm just hitting my shots," Harrison said. "I've been taking those shots all year, and now they're going in. "I didn't realize I made them all. I thought I missed one or two. I hit a left-handed shot that I was surprised went in." Colorado coach Ricardo Patton said Harrison's marksmanship was due to his taking better shots and not forcing shots when being double-teamed. "The biggest thing I've noticed is that he's getting better at passing out of the double teams," Patton said. "He's not panicking any more or hurrying as much to get it out." Colorado (12-6, 4-3 Big 12) also got 21 points from Michel Morandais. Harvey Thomas led Baylor (6-13, 1-5) with 19 points and 10 rebounds. R.T. Guinn had 13 points, and Terrance Thomas had 12 points and 10 rebounds. Colorado shot 59 percent, including 71 percent in the second half, compared to the Bears' 41 percent. "It's pick your poison with Colorado," Baylor coach Scott Drew said. "They have a great outside game and obviously Harrison in the middle. You can't stop both. "If you guard Harrison one-on-one, you can't stop him. I said at the beginning of the season that he's the top NBA prospect in the league, and he proved that tonight. Boy, I sure hope he goes pro at the end of the season." Terrance Thomas said the Bears "don't have enough depth to take care of David Harrison in the middle. He's too big and too strong for us." Baylor also was shorthanded when its best defender, Corey Herring, broke his hand in Saturday's shootaround. "That reduced us from seven scholarship guys to six," Drew said. "We went from the magnificant seven to the very fatigued six, especially in this altitude. We tried to slow it down so we would have a chance." Baylor, which trailed 40-24 at halftime, cut the deficit to 10 points on five occasions in the second half but could get no closer. Carl Marshall hit back-to-back 3-pointers, and Henry Thomas made a basket in the lane to trim the lead to 56-46 with 12:57 left. But Harrison scored 10 points the rest of the way, and Morandais had nine. The 7-foot Harrison made a three-point play on a driving layup with 8:32 remaining and had another three-point play on an alley-oop with 3:57 left, capping a 7-0 run for a 72-55 lead. The Buffaloes used runs of 12-0 and 9-0 in the first half to forge their 16-point halftime lead. Colorado outshot Baylor 48 percent to 36 percent in the half and outrebounded the Bears 22-11. Harrison had a three-point play, and Morandais hit three straight 3-pointers during the Buffs' 12-0 flurry that produced a 14-3 lead. Terrance Thomas hit a pair of 3-pointers, but Colorado countered with a 9-0 surge. Lamar Harris had a slam dunk on a pass from Harrison, and Harrison followed with a rebound layup. Harris hit two free throws, and Blair Wilson capped the run with a 3-pointer for a 30-11 lead with 6:35 left in the half. Henry Thomas scored four straight points for Baylor late in the half, but Colorado's Marcus Hall hit a 3-pointer with 15 seconds left.
